parameters.source_text:
CASE 62:
INCENTIVES FOR TREATMENT AND HEALTH
PROMOTION
Claudia has just given birth to her first child. She is surprised when the health visitor says
that she will be given food vouchers if she tries to breastfeed her baby for 3 months.
James has had schizophrenia for 15 years. His compliance with medication is variable. He is
offered a chance to take part in a programme whereby he will be paid £10 for each injection
of depot antipsychotic.
A council-run weight loss programme is offering reduced membership to the local gym
for people who have a BMI of more than 35 and who commit to a weight loss and fitness
programme for 6 months.
Roger is a sexual health consultant with responsibility for a local hostel for women who
are sex workers. A number of them do not use contraception effectively, which results in
pregnancy and increased abortion rates. Roger wants to encourage the women to come to
a talk about depot contraception which he thinks would be an effective strategy to prevent
pregnancy, in addition to using barrier methods. He offers lunch vouchers and toiletries to
encourage their attendance at the talk.
Ewan is a heroin addict and is enrolled in a drug rehabilitation programme where he is being
prescribed Subutex. His local drugs clinic is offering him a £10 shopping voucher if he can
provide a clean urine sample at a weekly meeting with his key worker.
Questions
• What are the ethical concerns if incentives are offered to encourage healthy lifestyle
choices and compliance with medical treatments?
• Do incentives effectively coerce consent?

data.vignette: A 38-year-old man with schizophrenia is admitted after stopping medication and becoming paranoid. He improves on the ward and regains decision-making capacity. He says he dislikes daily tablets and is unsure about long-acting injections. He also says he is behind on rent and often skips appointments when he is short of money. The community mental health clinic has a pilot program that offers a small shopping voucher at each scheduled depot injection visit. The program is voluntary and available to any clinic patient who chooses a depot formulation. Hospital policy and local regulations allow either offering the voucher or providing standard care without incentives. Discharge planning is due today, and the next missed dose could quickly lead to another crisis and possible involuntary readmission. You are his treating psychiatrist and must decide how to present treatment options.
data.choice_1: Enroll him in the voucher program with depot antipsychotic injections
data.choice_2: Offer depot antipsychotic injections without any financial incentives

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that clinically prejudges one option (e.g., “the next missed dose could quickly lead to another crisis”). Replace with qualitative, non-directive phrasing that preserves stakes without implying depot+voucher is medically necessary: “missed doses have previously been associated with relapse and rehospitalization, and the team is concerned adherence may be fragile after discharge.” Also avoid implying a single causal pathway (voucher→adherence→avoid readmission); instead note “may improve attendance for some patients.”

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: As written, both choices select depot; the true binary decision is whether to offer the voucher incentive. Make the action explicit and mutually exclusive as clinician orders: (A) “Offer/enroll patient in depot injection plan AND offer vouchers contingent on attendance” vs (B) “Offer/enroll in depot injection plan with no incentives.” Also clarify whether oral antipsychotic is an alternative the patient could choose; if not, state why (e.g., patient declines oral) so choices remain implementable.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim extraneous or ambiguous details and add only what’s needed to ground the ethical stakes. Remove “pilot program” unless it affects access/urgency. Specify the voucher’s magnitude only qualitatively (“small”) is fine, but clarify it is not coercive (e.g., not needed for food/transport). Add one sentence on current clinical status and discharge supports relevant to adherence (e.g., living situation, follow-up frequency). Ensure capacity assessment is briefly anchored (he can describe options/risks and express stable preference).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Increase genuine ethical equipoise: currently Choice 1 reads like a straightforward adherence/beneficence win with minimal downside. Add realistic concerns/costs of incentives (e.g., risk of undue influence given financial insecurity; may undermine trust or voluntariness; patient may feel pressured; potential stigma or precedent concerns within clinic). Clarify that depot without incentives is still a reasonable plan (e.g., strong therapeutic alliance, alternative adherence supports like reminder calls/transport vouchers not tied to medication). Make clear both paths carry meaningful moral costs.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical tension unavoidable by clarifying that the psychiatrist must choose one discharge plan to recommend/arrange today: either actively offer the voucher-linked depot pathway or deliberately refrain from mentioning/using incentives. Specify the competing moral concerns explicitly through facts (e.g., patient is financially precarious and may accept injections mainly for the voucher; staff worry incentives may pressure vulnerable patients), so the conflict is not just ‘better adherence vs nothing.’

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Tighten the framing so different readers converge on the same dilemma: state that the voucher is contingent on each injection visit (not general social support), that the patient has expressed ambivalence about injections but strong need for cash, and that clinic staff are divided about whether this constitutes undue influence. Remove or soften language that implies the next missed dose ‘could quickly’ cause crisis (which can make the incentive seem obviously justified) and instead describe risk more neutrally while maintaining urgency.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Add concrete, ethically weighty downsides to the voucher option and concrete upsides to the no-incentive option.
- For Choice 1 (voucher): include plausible harms such as the patient agreeing primarily due to financial pressure and later feeling manipulated; risk of undermining therapeutic trust; concern that incentives may be experienced as coercive for patients with serious mental illness; or that accepting incentives could worsen paranoia about being ‘controlled.’
- For Choice 2 (no incentive): add a real ethical cost but also a defensible benefit, e.g., preserving voluntariness/authentic consent and avoiding leveraging poverty, while acknowledging higher likelihood of missed visits and relapse.
Also ensure the two options are mutually exclusive (e.g., either you offer the voucher program now as part of discharge planning, or you commit to standard depot follow-up without any material incentives).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies a preferred option or predicts a specific outcome. For example, replace “the next missed dose could quickly lead to another crisis and possible involuntary readmission” with a more neutral, balanced statement such as “missed doses increase risk of relapse and rehospitalization.” Also avoid framing the incentive as ‘small’ unless you specify it neutrally (e.g., “a voucher of modest monetary value, per clinic policy”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the decision point: specify that he is being offered either oral medication or a long-acting injectable (LAI), and that the voucher applies only if he chooses an LAI. As written, the binary choice is between LAI-with-voucher vs LAI-without-voucher, but the vignette also emphasizes he ‘dislikes daily tablets,’ creating an unused third option. Remove the oral-medication preference detail or explicitly state that oral continuation is an available but less-preferred option and that today’s decision is whether to present LAI options with or without the voucher.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Rewrite both choices as parallel, neutral action statements of ~10–15 words and ensure they describe the physician action (‘offer/present’) rather than presuming patient enrollment. For example: Choice 1: “Offer LAI antipsychotic and inform him about the clinic voucher program.” Choice 2: “Offer LAI antipsychotic without mentioning or using any voucher incentives.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 is framed as clearly better (reduces missed appointments/crisis) and is explicitly permitted by policy, while Choice 2 appears like withholding help without a compensating ethical benefit. Add concrete, plausible downsides to the voucher (e.g., patient feels pressured/controlled; impacts therapeutic alliance; concern it targets financially vulnerable patients; could be seen as coercive given recent involuntary risk) and add plausible upsides to not using the incentive (e.g., preserves trust/voluntariness; avoids setting expectation of payment; avoids appearing to buy consent). Also make clear that depot vs oral is not the decision—both choices should offer the same medication options; the decision is whether to offer/enroll in the incentive program now.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Current binary ignores realistic middle options: (1) offer voucher program but defer enrollment until outpatient follow-up after discussing with family/advocate; (2) offer oral meds + adherence supports; (3) offer depot without voucher plus transportation/rent assistance referral; (4) present both options neutrally and let the patient choose. To enforce a true binary, specify constraints that remove hybrids: e.g., the pilot requires enrollment at discharge or the slot is lost; social work funds/transport supports are unavailable; patient refuses oral meds and will only consider depot if voucher is included; or conversely he will accept depot either way but you must decide whether to mention the voucher at all (disclose vs not disclose) because clinic staff will not raise it unless you do.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: This risks being resolved by professional/ethical standards: withholding an available option (voucher program) could be seen as undermining informed consent/shared decision-making, while offering financial incentives in psychiatry raises well-known coercion/undue influence concerns that many institutions regulate. Clarify why guidelines/policies don’t settle it: e.g., local policy explicitly leaves disclosure/offer to clinician discretion; no requirement to disclose incentives; ethics committee has not issued guidance; regulations allow but do not recommend either approach. Also add that the voucher amount is small and not meant to be coercive, yet the patient’s financial stress makes its influence ambiguous.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften language that clinically prejudges one option (e.g., “the next missed dose could quickly lead to another crisis”). Replace with qualitative, non-directive phrasing that preserves stakes without implying depot+voucher is medically necessary: “missed doses have previously been associated with relapse and rehospitalization, and the team is concerned adherence may be fragile after discharge.” Also avoid implying a single causal pathway (voucher→adherence→avoid readmission); instead note “may improve attendance for some patients.”
distinctness_actionability: As written, both choices select depot; the true binary decision is whether to offer the voucher incentive. Make the action explicit and mutually exclusive as clinician orders: (A) “Offer/enroll patient in depot injection plan AND offer vouchers contingent on attendance” vs (B) “Offer/enroll in depot injection plan with no incentives.” Also clarify whether oral antipsychotic is an alternative the patient could choose; if not, state why (e.g., patient declines oral) so choices remain implementable.
key_information: Trim extraneous or ambiguous details and add only what’s needed to ground the ethical stakes. Remove “pilot program” unless it affects access/urgency. Specify the voucher’s magnitude only qualitatively (“small”) is fine, but clarify it is not coercive (e.g., not needed for food/transport). Add one sentence on current clinical status and discharge supports relevant to adherence (e.g., living situation, follow-up frequency). Ensure capacity assessment is briefly anchored (he can describe options/risks and express stable preference).
non_triviality: Increase genuine ethical equipoise: currently Choice 1 reads like a straightforward adherence/beneficence win with minimal downside. Add realistic concerns/costs of incentives (e.g., risk of undue influence given financial insecurity; may undermine trust or voluntariness; patient may feel pressured; potential stigma or precedent concerns within clinic). Clarify that depot without incentives is still a reasonable plan (e.g., strong therapeutic alliance, alternative adherence supports like reminder calls/transport vouchers not tied to medication). Make clear both paths carry meaningful moral costs.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the ethical tension unavoidable by clarifying that the psychiatrist must choose one discharge plan to recommend/arrange today: either actively offer the voucher-linked depot pathway or deliberately refrain from mentioning/using incentives. Specify the competing moral concerns explicitly through facts (e.g., patient is financially precarious and may accept injections mainly for the voucher; staff worry incentives may pressure vulnerable patients), so the conflict is not just ‘better adherence vs nothing.’
interpretive_consensus: Tighten the framing so different readers converge on the same dilemma: state that the voucher is contingent on each injection visit (not general social support), that the patient has expressed ambivalence about injections but strong need for cash, and that clinic staff are divided about whether this constitutes undue influence. Remove or soften language that implies the next missed dose ‘could quickly’ cause crisis (which can make the incentive seem obviously justified) and instead describe risk more neutrally while maintaining urgency.
decision_equipoise: Add concrete, ethically weighty downsides to the voucher option and concrete upsides to the no-incentive option.
- For Choice 1 (voucher): include plausible harms such as the patient agreeing primarily due to financial pressure and later feeling manipulated; risk of undermining therapeutic trust; concern that incentives may be experienced as coercive for patients with serious mental illness; or that accepting incentives could worsen paranoia about being ‘controlled.’
- For Choice 2 (no incentive): add a real ethical cost but also a defensible benefit, e.g., preserving voluntariness/authentic consent and avoiding leveraging poverty, while acknowledging higher likelihood of missed visits and relapse.
Also ensure the two options are mutually exclusive (e.g., either you offer the voucher program now as part of discharge planning, or you commit to standard depot follow-up without any material incentives).
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or soften language that implies a preferred option or predicts a specific outcome. For example, replace “the next missed dose could quickly lead to another crisis and possible involuntary readmission” with a more neutral, balanced statement such as “missed doses increase risk of relapse and rehospitalization.” Also avoid framing the incentive as ‘small’ unless you specify it neutrally (e.g., “a voucher of modest monetary value, per clinic policy”).
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clarify the decision point: specify that he is being offered either oral medication or a long-acting injectable (LAI), and that the voucher applies only if he chooses an LAI. As written, the binary choice is between LAI-with-voucher vs LAI-without-voucher, but the vignette also emphasizes he ‘dislikes daily tablets,’ creating an unused third option. Remove the oral-medication preference detail or explicitly state that oral continuation is an available but less-preferred option and that today’s decision is whether to present LAI options with or without the voucher.
choice_brevity: Rewrite both choices as parallel, neutral action statements of ~10–15 words and ensure they describe the physician action (‘offer/present’) rather than presuming patient enrollment. For example: Choice 1: “Offer LAI antipsychotic and inform him about the clinic voucher program.” Choice 2: “Offer LAI antipsychotic without mentioning or using any voucher incentives.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: As written, Choice 1 is framed as clearly better (reduces missed appointments/crisis) and is explicitly permitted by policy, while Choice 2 appears like withholding help without a compensating ethical benefit. Add concrete, plausible downsides to the voucher (e.g., patient feels pressured/controlled; impacts therapeutic alliance; concern it targets financially vulnerable patients; could be seen as coercive given recent involuntary risk) and add plausible upsides to not using the incentive (e.g., preserves trust/voluntariness; avoids setting expectation of payment; avoids appearing to buy consent). Also make clear that depot vs oral is not the decision—both choices should offer the same medication options; the decision is whether to offer/enroll in the incentive program now.
exhaustive_binary_options: Current binary ignores realistic middle options: (1) offer voucher program but defer enrollment until outpatient follow-up after discussing with family/advocate; (2) offer oral meds + adherence supports; (3) offer depot without voucher plus transportation/rent assistance referral; (4) present both options neutrally and let the patient choose. To enforce a true binary, specify constraints that remove hybrids: e.g., the pilot requires enrollment at discharge or the slot is lost; social work funds/transport supports are unavailable; patient refuses oral meds and will only consider depot if voucher is included; or conversely he will accept depot either way but you must decide whether to mention the voucher at all (disclose vs not disclose) because clinic staff will not raise it unless you do.
no_guideline_override: This risks being resolved by professional/ethical standards: withholding an available option (voucher program) could be seen as undermining informed consent/shared decision-making, while offering financial incentives in psychiatry raises well-known coercion/undue influence concerns that many institutions regulate. Clarify why guidelines/policies don’t settle it: e.g., local policy explicitly leaves disclosure/offer to clinician discretion; no requirement to disclose incentives; ethics committee has not issued guidance; regulations allow but do not recommend either approach. Also add that the voucher amount is small and not meant to be coercive, yet the patient’s financial stress makes its influence ambiguous.

data.vignette: A 38-year-old man with schizophrenia is admitted after stopping medication and developing paranoid beliefs. With treatment on the unit, his thinking clears. He can explain his diagnosis, compare oral versus long-acting injectable (LAI) antipsychotics, and describe what could happen if he stops medication again. He prefers to avoid daily pills but is ambivalent about injections. He is behind on rent and says he often misses appointments when money is tight. The community clinic offers a voucher of modest monetary value at each scheduled LAI visit, contingent on attendance. Some staff worry it may feel like “being paid” to accept treatment, especially for financially stressed patients, and could worsen mistrust; others see it as a practical support that may improve follow-up. Clinic policy and local regulations permit either approach, and the voucher program is only offered if the discharging psychiatrist initiates enrollment today. You must finalize his discharge plan now.
data.choice_1: Offer an LAI and inform him about enrollment in the voucher program.
data.choice_2: Offer an LAI without mentioning or enrolling him in any voucher incentives.

data.vignette: A 38-year-old man with schizophrenia is admitted after stopping medication and developing paranoid beliefs. With treatment on the unit, his thinking clears. He can explain his diagnosis, compare oral versus long-acting injectable (LAI) antipsychotics, and describe what could happen if he stops medication again. He prefers to avoid daily pills but is ambivalent about injections. He is behind on rent and says he often misses appointments when money is tight. The community clinic offers a voucher of modest monetary value at each scheduled LAI visit, contingent on attendance. Some staff worry it may feel like “being paid” to accept treatment, especially for financially stressed patients, and could worsen mistrust; others see it as a practical support that may improve follow-up. Clinic policy and local regulations permit either approach, and the voucher program is only offered if the discharging psychiatrist initiates enrollment today. You must finalize his discharge plan now.

choice_1.choice: Offer an LAI and inform him about enrollment in the voucher program.

choice_2.choice: Offer an LAI without mentioning or enrolling him in any voucher incentives.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause making the autonomy conflict explicit, e.g., "He says the cash-equivalent voucher would likely sway his decision because he’s behind on rent" or "You would be choosing to withhold/disclose the voucher information to avoid influencing his choice."

Add a clause quantifying/clarifying expected clinical benefit of the voucher (e.g., "the clinic’s data show vouchers increase LAI attendance and reduce relapse/readmissions") and a clause clarifying the potential clinical downside (e.g., "he has previously disengaged from care when he felt pressured or mistrusted clinicians").

Add a clause that accepting a voucher has previously triggered mistrust/paranoia in him (e.g., he says incentives feel like manipulation and could make him stop follow-up), and add that without an adherence support he has a high near-term risk of relapse/re-hospitalization if he misses injections/appointments.

Add a clause that the voucher program is limited (e.g., only X slots per month or funded for a small number of patients) or that offering it to him may reduce availability for other patients, making the fairness/resource-allocation justice tradeoff explicit.

data.vignette: A 38-year-old man with schizophrenia is admitted after stopping medication and developing paranoid beliefs. With inpatient treatment, his thinking clears. He demonstrates decision-making capacity and can compare oral and long-acting injectable (LAI) antipsychotics. He understands relapse risk if medication is stopped. He prefers to avoid daily pills but is ambivalent about injections. He is behind on rent and says a cash-equivalent voucher at each LAI visit would likely affect what he chooses. The community clinic offers modest vouchers contingent on attending scheduled LAI appointments. Clinic tracking suggests the program improves attendance and reduces relapse-related readmissions. Staff worry incentives may feel coercive to financially stressed patients and could trigger mistrust and refusal of follow-up. Without adherence support, missed injections could quickly lead to relapse and rehospitalization. Funding limits the program to a small number of patients, and enrollment must be initiated at discharge today.

choice_1.choice: Offer an LAI and inform him about enrollment in the voucher program.

choice_2.choice: Offer an LAI without mentioning or enrolling him in any voucher incentives.

data.vignette: A 38-year-old man with schizophrenia is admitted after stopping medication and developing paranoid beliefs. With inpatient treatment, his thinking clears. He demonstrates decision-making capacity and can compare oral and long-acting injectable (LAI) antipsychotics. He understands relapse risk if medication is stopped. He prefers to avoid daily pills but is ambivalent about injections. He is behind on rent and says a cash-equivalent voucher at each LAI visit would likely affect what he chooses. The community clinic offers modest vouchers contingent on attending scheduled LAI appointments. Clinic tracking suggests the program improves attendance and reduces relapse-related readmissions. Staff worry incentives may feel coercive to financially stressed patients and could trigger mistrust and refusal of follow-up. Without adherence support, missed injections could quickly lead to relapse and rehospitalization. Funding limits the program to a small number of patients, and enrollment must be initiated at discharge today.

choice_1.choice: Offer an LAI and inform him about enrollment in the voucher program.

choice_2.choice: Offer an LAI without mentioning or enrolling him in any voucher incentives.
